titleStmt.title: Nevves from France. A true relation of the great losses which happened by the lamentable accident of fire in the citie of Paris, the 24. day of October last past, 1621 which burnt downe the Merchants Bridge, the Changers Bridge, and diuers houses neere vnto them. Together with the speedy diligence vsed by the Duke De Monbason, gouernour of the said towne, for the quenching thereof. Also a decree made in the Court of Parliament in Paris, whereby an order is taken for prouiding for the merchants that haue lost their goods by the sayd fire, and to preuent the like mischance in time to come. Translated according to the French copie, printed at Paris.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: NEWES FROM FRANCE.
div.p:
GOD, who≈øe goodne≈ø≈øe and clemencie is incomprehen≈øible, to our humane thoughts and imaginations, doth not alwayes di≈øcharge the arrowes of his wrath vpon mi≈øerable ≈øinners; who by the innumerablene≈ø≈øe of their offences, haue ≈øtirred vp and prouoked his wrath again≈øt them, becau≈øe he de≈øireth not the death of a ≈øinner, but rather that he ≈øhould conuert and be ≈øaued: But when he ≈øeeth that they waxe wor≈øe, and are hardened in their ≈øinnes, and lull them≈øelues a≈øleepe in humane delights: Then he rouzeth vp him≈øelfe with the ≈øcourge of aduer≈øitie, and di≈øchargeth the furie of his wrath again≈øt them, to make them turne vnto him, who is the Soueraigne Ruler, of whome they hold their being, and all their power. Then (I ≈øay) he employeth the great forces of the heauens,
and the Elements, thereby to heale the vlcer of their vices, that wallow and take plea≈øure in ≈øinne, as a Sow delighteth to wallow in the mire.

Which plainely appeareth by the deplorable accident happened of late in the Citie of Paris, where the force and furie of fire ≈øtrucke ≈øuch an a≈øtoni≈øhment in all the inhabitants, that they thought the Towne, like a ≈øecond Sodome, would ≈øuddenly haue beene con≈øumed to a≈øhes, by the impetuous flames of fire that threatned them; and yet could not truely know the truth how it began: For it is ≈øo diuer≈øly reported, that men cannot a≈ø≈øuredly declare any truth thereof: And it is prohibited by a Decree made in Court of Parliament, in any ≈øort to ≈øpeake thereof, to ≈øhunne and auoid the tumult and commotion of the people. But ≈øo it is, that vpon Saturday the 23. of October, about one of the clocke after midnight, the fire began in ≈øuch manner to flame out vpon the Merchants Bridge, that the inhabitants thereof were ≈øurprized ≈øleeping in their beds, before they heard or perceiued it: for the fire (which met with nothing el≈øe but that which was combu≈øtible) increa≈øed with ≈øuch
impetuo≈øitie, that in a ≈øhort time, all the hou≈øes that ≈øtood vpon the ≈øaid Bridge on both ≈øides, were on fire, by meanes of certaine beames that lay cro≈ø≈øe ouer one to another.

The Change Bridge did no le≈ø≈øe feele the force and vigour which the ≈øaid fire vomited out, by meanes of the flames i≈ø≈øuing from the ≈øame: for that de≈øcending downe to the foundations thereof, in the end it burnt and ca≈øt it into the water, with all the hou≈øes ≈øtanding thereon, together with the great riches of the inhabitants, that by no meanes could ≈øaue any thing thereof, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømoake and heate, that hurt and choked diuers of the people, and ≈øome men that were burnt, fell down with the beames and peeces of wood all burning into the riuer.

You may iudge how many children and poore innocent ≈øoules were buried in that impiteous fire, for that their fathers and mothers had worke enough to doe, to ≈øaue them≈øelues. Many women newly brought in bed, and others that were ≈øicke in their beds, payd that debt to nature, which all of vs one day mu≈øt doe, neither hauing that force nor dexteritie ≈øufficient to ≈øaue them≈øelues. It was mo≈øt lamentable
to heare the wofull cries and ≈øighings, not onely of tho≈øe that were afflicted, but al≈øo of the ≈øpectators of that mi≈øerable accident: The men in great feare ≈øaued them≈øelues from that vnexpected deluge, in a manner halfe dead, blaming the heauens for their di≈øa≈øter, and not knowing how to bee reuenged for their lo≈ø≈øe, tooke reuenge vpon them≈øelues; and men were as much troubled to comfort them, as to ≈øaue the re≈øt of tho≈øe that were within their hou≈øes. Women in extreme di≈øcomfort, their haire hanging about their heades, and in a manner naked, beholding that horrible ≈øpectacle, bathing their faces with teares, and ca≈øting a thou≈øand ≈øighes vp into the ayre, ≈øwouned, and in a manner fell into de≈øpaire. Diuers ≈øeruants, both maides and men, as well as their ma≈øters and mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes, induring and feeling the rigor of that mi≈øchance, ≈øtood in the like manner as others did, ready to pay their debt to cruell de≈øtiny.

The fire ≈øtill waxing greater and greater, mounted vp into the ayre with mighty flames, and ca≈øt ≈øuch and ≈øo great a light ouer all the Citie, that tho≈øe which knew nothing of that vnfortunate mi≈øchance, being awaked
by the popular rumour, were in a maze, to imagine from whence that light ≈øhould come, not knowing the cau≈øe; but as others did, in great feare ranne vnto the place.

The Bels in diuers Churches began to ring, the noy≈øe whereof a≈øtoni≈øhing diuers Citizens of the ≈øayd Towne, cau≈øed them to arme them≈øelues: at which time Paris began to enter into a great tumult. When the Duke de Monba≈øon, Gouernour of the City, hauing intelligence thereof, came vnto the place with his Company of ≈øouldiers, the Watch, and diuers others; all in Armes, placing a Court of guard at both ends of the Bridges, and other places. From thence he went to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt eminent places, as the Ba≈øtille, the Kings Court called the Louure, the Towne hou≈øe, and diuers places of note; which done, he cau≈øed fires to be made thorowout all the Citie, and Lanternes to bee hung out of euery window, in ≈øo great quantity, that it was as light as at noone-day: and cau≈øed foure Culuerins to be brought to both the ends of the ≈øaid Bridges: and to conclude, v≈øed ≈øuch diligence in that imminent danger, ≈øtill keeping good watch, doubting ≈øome
trea≈øon, that he is perpetually to be commended for the ≈øame.

In the meane time, while he was thus prouidently bu≈øied about that publike care, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary in ≈øuch an extremitie: The fire, that like a tempe≈øt, deuoured and ≈øpoyled all that it tooke hold on, was not content with that whereon it had fir≈øt ≈øeized, but hauing ≈øatisfied the greedie de≈øire thereof, and brought all the hou≈øes and dwelling places vpon the ≈øayd two Bridges, into vtter ruine and de≈øolation, and layd them in the valley of mi≈øerie, encrea≈øed more and more, and carried her flames into the Galue place; and if it had not beene for ≈øome artificiall trenches, and mens helpe, who in great numbers ranne thither, the great Ca≈øtle, and the gate of Paris, was in danger to haue felt the furie thereof. On the other ≈øide, in the extremitie of the raging flames, at the other end of the Bridges afore≈øaid, the fire was no le≈ø≈øe furious: for hauing ≈øeized vpon all the hou≈øes and ≈øhops neere vnto it, as farre as before the Pallace, it tooke hold on the Dyall, and beganne to melt the Lead that couered it, vntill a great number of nimble and couragious men, ran thither, and
employed all their forces and indu≈øtries, to ≈øaue that admirable worke.

The Duke de Monba≈øon, while euery man was bu≈øied about that pitifull and mo≈øt lamentable bu≈øines, on Sunday in the morning, cau≈øed commandement to bee made by ≈øound of Trumpet, that all the Citizens ≈øhould fill and ≈øet diuers tubs full of water at all the corners of the ≈øtreetes. And it is an incredible thing to report, how great a number of people from all places ranne vnto that place, to ≈øatisfie them≈øelues with the ≈øight of that horrible fire, which filled their eyes with teares, and their bre≈øts with ≈øighes.

This (friendly Reader) in briefe is the true relation that I can make vnto thee, to let thee know and vnder≈øtand this lamentable action: from whence the ≈øame proceeded no man knowes. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, the Court, by a Decree made the 25. day of Octob. hath commanded all Iudges and Officers to make an exact enquirie of tho≈øe, that wickedly haue committed that di≈øorder; and that the knowledge thereof being had, ≈øo good Iu≈øtice may be v≈øed therein, that ≈øuch as they may take example thereby.

div.head: A Decree made by the Court of Parliament in PARIS, whereby Order is taken for prouiding for the Merchants, that haue lo≈øt their goods by the ≈øaid fire, and to preuent the like mi≈øchance in time to come.
div.p:
VPon the Declaration made by the Kings Atturney General, touching the fire happened by night, betweene Saturday and Sunday, the 24. of this moneth of October, which burnt and con≈øumed the Changers and the Merchants Bridges, and ≈øome hou≈øes neere vnto them, as well on the Palace ≈øide, vnto the Leather ≈øtreet, as on the great Ca≈øtle ≈øide, requiring, That the Court would be plea≈øed, to giue him Commi≈ø≈øion to make information of the beginning of that fire, con≈øidering the diuers reports that were ≈øpred abroad in the Towne, that might bee a meanes to procure great trouble in the ≈øame, and to make ≈øpeedie proui≈øion for the nece≈ø≈øitie of tho≈øe, that haue lo≈øt their goods by the ≈øaid Fire, as al≈øo that the like inconuenience may not happen. After the Lieutenant ciuill, and the ≈øub≈øtitute of the ≈øayd
Atturney generall had audience, being for that cau≈øe ≈øent for, vpon information that they had begunne to make inquirie thereof.

The Court hath enjoyned and enioyneth the Prouo≈øt of Paris, or his Lieutenants ciuill or criminall, diligently to continue the information by them begun, touching the originall of that Fire, and to make and fini≈øh the inditement of the authours of the ≈øame, and their adherents, ready for the definitiue ≈øentence, notwith≈øtanding any oppo≈øitions, or appeales what≈øoeuer: and to the Sub≈øtitute of the ≈øayd Atturney generall to be a≈ø≈øi≈øtant vnto them, and with all diligence to certifie this Court thereof. And withall, expre≈ø≈øely command and prohibite (vpon paine of death) all per≈øons, of what qualities or conditions ≈øoeuer they be, to a≈ø≈øemble together either by day or by night, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee by commandement of the Magi≈øtrate, nor yet to mi≈ø behaue them≈øelues by words, nor to v≈øe any reproches, vnder pretence of diuer≈øitie of Religions, or to ≈øow or ca≈øt foorth any bruites or rumours touching the inconuenience of the ≈øayd Fire, tending to the di≈øquietne≈ø≈øe of the Citie; but to liue peaceably and quietly, vnder the Kings Authority and Edicts. Commanding
all vagrant per≈øons, and men that are of lewde conuer≈øation, liuing idlely, pre≈øently, without any delay, to depart out of the Citie, after the publication of the≈øe pre≈øents: And their Oa≈øts, and ≈øuch as harbour them, to di≈øclo≈øe them, vpon paine per≈øonally to an≈øwere for them: And to prouide for the nece≈ø≈øitie and reliefe of the poore inhabitants, vtterly vndone and beggered by the ≈øayd Fire: Humble ≈øupplication ≈øhall be made vnto the King, to be plea≈øed to be≈øtow His gracious liberalitie vpon them. And in the meane time it is ordeined, That the ≈øaid Atturney generall ≈øhall make a note of the names of tho≈øe, that haue endured the ≈øaid lo≈ø≈øes; and what trades and occupations they were of, as al≈øo of the number of their children and families, who may be put into Saint Louis Hou≈øe, there to be lodged and nouri≈øhed for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe moneths: and to that end, there ≈øhall be ten thou≈øand Frankes put into the hands of Perrot and Sainctot, Ouer≈øeers of the Ho≈øpitall. And further, that gatherings ≈øhall be made throughout all the Pari≈øhes of this Citie, to ayde the ≈øaid di≈øtre≈ø≈øed people. And to that end, the people ≈øhall be exhorted by the Vicars: and Officers of the ≈øayd Pari≈øhes, to appoint certaine per≈øons of
good qualitie, from month to month, to make the ≈øayd Gatherings. Commanding the Prouo≈øt of Merchants and Sheriffes, to ≈øet men on worke continually, to take vp, and rid away the ruines of the ≈øaid Fire fallen into the water, that the cour≈øe of the ≈øame may not be hindred, and to make it nauigable: and in the meane time, to appoint hone≈øt men of good credit, and well experienced, for the ≈øpace of a whole yeere, to ≈øearch in the bottome of the water, for the goods and merchandizes, that ≈øhall be found to haue beene drowned; and the ≈øame to bee brought into the common Ho≈øpitall of the ≈øaid Citie; whereof an Inuentorie ≈øhall bee made by one of the ≈øayd Sheriffes, that they may bee re≈øtored to the owners thereof. And al≈øo that all Boatmen, and ≈øuch as v≈øe to ≈øaile vp and downe the riuer; and all others, that ≈øhall haue found any thing of the ≈øame, to bring them to the ≈øaid Ho≈øpitall of the Towne, and to bring a certificate thereof, vpon paine of hanging. We likewi≈øe command the Prouo≈øt of Merchants, and the Sheriffes, to keepe and hold within the ≈øayd Ho≈øpitall of the Towne, and the Towne-hou≈øe, as al≈øo in euery Ward, ≈øuch a quantity of hooks,
buckets of lether, and other ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øaries as ≈øhall be needfull in time to come, to ≈øerue for ≈øuch inconueniences of Fire, and to certifie the ≈øame vnto the Clerke of the ≈øaid Court. And the Captaine of the Watch, to keepe good watch by night in the Palace, and other v≈øuall places. And to the end, in time to come, that the danger of Fire may not take in the Palace, by rea≈øon of the ≈øhoppes that are built vp again≈øt the ≈øame, We ordeine and command, that the new ≈øhops built from the Dyall Tower, to the bailliage Gate, on the Quay-≈øide of the riuer, ≈øhall be pulled downe; and none of them to be built vp againe for any cau≈øe or rea≈øon what≈øoeuer. And further, that all Proce≈ø≈øes ≈øued out again≈øt the bodies of tho≈øe that dwelt vpon the ≈øayd Bridges, by rea≈øon of any Obligations, Iudgements, or Arre≈øts, in what manner ≈øoeuer they be done, ≈øhall ≈øurcea≈øe for the ≈øpace of a yeere: and that by the ordinarie Iudges there ≈øhall bee ≈øufficient delay made, con≈øidering their lo≈ø≈øe; and what≈øoeuer ≈øhall by them bee ordeined, to be put in execution; notwith≈øtanding any oppo≈øitions or appeales what≈øoeuer. And this pre≈øent Decree ≈øhall, by the diligence of the Atturney
generall, bee publi≈øhed, as well in the Church Porches, as openly by ≈øound of Trumpet, and ≈øet vp vpon the corners of the ≈øtreetes.
